page.title: 04History (1)
page.content: A Bronze Age ring has been identified on former heathland and there is much scttered evidence of Roman occupation, particularly along the south facing slopes of the Bramfield Brook. The remains include pottery, glass, coins and tiles which suggest a settlement site. Consensus agrees that the name Wenhaston is derived from Wenheards Farm. Few old buildings in village, or in Bramfield or Thorington. Very little earlier than 16th C.. Rose Glen and the Guildhall Cottages in Wenhaston date from mid 15th C. A number of barns also date from this period -e.g. at Church Farm Thorington.
